Award.AwardTitle: Travel Support for US Physicists to the 27th IUPAP Triennial Conference on Thermodynamics and Statistical Mechanics (STATPHYS-27) Buenos Aires, Argentina 2019
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award partially supports the participation of approximately 25 US-based graduate students, postdocs, and early-career participants without grant support in the STATPHYS-27 conference that will take place in Buenos Aires, Argentina, in July 2019. This is an instance of a series of established and successful international triennial conferences on statistical physics that attract a diverse group of approximately 1500 US and international researchers in statistical physics and related fields. Leading researchers and students from around the world will meet at the STATPHYS-27 conference to discuss the latest advances in statistical physics and related
fields, and to identify the most important and promising new directions for future research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this grant was to provide support for the participation of US scientists in the 27th triannial International Conference of Statistical Physics that was held in Buenos Aires (Argentina) in July 2019. This grant supplied much needed funding for the airfare and registration costs of 17 US scientists. This conference is organized by the International Union of Pure and Applied Physics, an international organization in which the American Physical Sociaty is one of its key members.

The STATPHYS
conference series is the most significant series of international meetings in statistical mechanics. Every three years it is held on a different continent to maximize its global relevance and visibility. It regularly attracts leading scientists from all parts of the world. The scientific content of this conference is much broader than that of local conferences. It is relevant to scientists from many different disciplines, including physics, biophysics, geophysics, biology, applied mathematics, computational sciences, chemistry, materials science, mechanical engineering, civil engineering, chemical engineering,
bioengineering and others. It thus provides unique opportunities for the development of crossdisciplinary, national and international collaborations, as it connects researchers from a wide range of subdisciplines in statistical
mechanics.

This conference in held every three years and changes location (country and continent) every time is held. The moving location of the meeting (on a different continent every 3 years) makes this meeting a truly global scientific effort with maximum international relevance and visibility. The conference series started in 1948 in Florence, and quickly grew in size and importance. After the influential1968 meeting in Kyoto, the conference kept growing in importance and size, moving to Chicago, Amsterdam, Budapest, Haifa, Edmonton, Edinburgh, Boston, Rio, Berlin, Xiamen, Paris, Cancun,
Bangalore, Genoa, Cairns, Seoul, Lyon, and, in 2019, to Buenos Aires.

The conference was held and it was a great success. It was attended by 720
participants from 41 countries, of which 334 were from Latin America, 236 from Europe, 89 from Asia/Pacific, and 61 from North America (56 from the US). Of the 720 participants, 570 male participants and 150 female participants. The conference lasted for five days. There were 11 plenary talks (3 from the US), 30 invited talks (3 from the US), and 225 contributed talks. There were a total of 255 talks in parallel sessions and 416 posters.
